data.name: What is a Matrix? (& Transposes)
data.description: A matrix is essentially a container of scalar numbers.

data.name: Matrix Multiplication
data.description: Calculate the product of two matrices

data.name: Inversion & Singular Matrices
data.description: Inversion is the process of find the matrix that multiplies a matrix to produce the identity matrix. Singular matrices are non-invertible.

data.name: Linear Equations (Ax=b)
data.description: Using linear algebra to solve linear equations

data.name: Vector Spaces & Basis
data.description: A vector space is a set of vectors in which any scalar multiplication can occur and the result remains in the space

data.name: Random Variables
data.description: Variables whose possible values are numerical outcomes of a random phenomenon

data.name: Probability Axioms
data.description: The fundamental rules of probability theory

data.name: Expectations
data.description: What you would expect the value of random variables to be on average

data.name: Conditional Probability & Independence
data.description: The rules governing different random variables that are correlated or depend on one another

data.name: Variance
data.description: Variance is a measure of the spread of data from their mean value

data.name: Bayes' Theorem
data.description: Bayes' theorem describes the probability of an event, based on prior knowledge of conditions that might be related to the event.

data.name: Differentiation
data.description: Differentation is the process of finding the differential of a function, which is a function describing the sensitivity to change of it's argument

data.name: Product Rule
data.description: A method for finding the derivatives of the products of two or more functions

data.name: Chain Rule
data.description: The chain rule provides a method of finding the derivative of composite functions. Knowing the change in z relative y and change in y relative to x lets us find the rate of change of z relative to x.

data.name: Integration
data.description: Methods for finding the area under a curve of a function

data.name: Cost functions
data.description: Measures of how wrong a model is in estimating the relationship between it's inputs and the desired output

data.name: Intro to Optimisation
data.description: The process of maximising or minimizing a function by systematically choosing input values

data.name: Ax=b Least Squares
data.description: A method for estimating unknown parameters based on mimizing the squared distance between datapoints and a regression line

data.name: Linear Regression
data.lectures: Linear Algebra course 14-24,      Machine Learning week 1-2
data.description: A linear approach to esitimating the relationship between an depedent and independent variables

data.name: Central Limit Theorem
data.description: In populations with a mean and standard deviation, if you take a sufficient number of samples, the means of those samples will be normally distributed

data.name: Gaussian Distribution
data.description: A continuous probability distribution to approximate random variables. Also known as the 'normal distribution' or informally as the 'bell curve'

data.name: Covariance
data.description: A measure of the strength of correlation between two or more random variables

data.name: Entropy
data.description: The measure of uncertainty associated with the values taken by a random variable. Can also be described as the quantity of information in a set of random variables

data.name: Classification: Logistic regression & softmax
data.description: Classification is learning to categorise data into groups based on labels. In more mathematical vernacular, classification is the umbrella term for supervised learning problems with discrete output space.

data.name: Gradient Descent
data.description: A large family of optimisation algorithms based on a simple observation: to reach the bottom of a valley, try walking downhill.

data.name: Regularization & Overfitting
data.description: Overfitting is a perennial problem in machine learning. If a model is only effective on the dataset it was trained on, and doesn't generalise to the wider world, it isn't useful. Regularization is umbrella term for methods used to mitigate overfitting.

data.name: Perceptrons & Neural Networks
data.description: The basis of deep learning - that a network of connected neurons have the capacity to learn amazingly powerful and varied representations. This concept starts focused on the simplest case - one neuron - and builds up to many.

data.name: Activation Functions
data.description: Biological neurons are typically modelled as firing when a threshold is reached. These provide similar non-linearities in artifical neurons.

data.name: Backpropagation
data.description: The fundamental algorithm that enables training machine learning models with supervised learning, backpropagation updates model parameters to improve its predictions.

data.name: Ensemble Methods
data.description: Instead of relying on the inference of one trained neural network, train many (an ensemble), typically with different architectures, datasets or hyperparameters and average across them

data.name: Dropout
data.description: A method for regularizing neural networks that approximates training neural networks with many different architectures at once. Reduces the reliance on any individual node.

data.name: Convolutional Neural Networks
data.description: The fundamental technology underlying all current state-of-the-art approaches to all computer vision problems. Uses a set of learned filters to extract features from images at different scales.

data.name: K-means clustering
data.description: An unsupervised learning algorithm that learns to cluster data points into distinct groups based on their values.

data.name: Probabilistic Graphical Models
data.description: A large family of probabilistic methods describing the relationships between random variables

data.name: LSTM
data.description: Long Short-Term Memory (or LSTM for short) recurrent neural network neurons take inputs word-embeddings one-by-one.

data.name: Symmetric Matrices
data.description: A square matrix that is equal to it's transpose. In other words, it's symmetric around the main diagonal of the matrix

data.name: Positive Definite Matrices
data.description: A key family of matrices with interesting properties and a wide array of use cases.

data.name: Markov Matrices
data.description: A Markov matrix is a square matrix with all nonnegative entries, and where the sum of the entries down any column is 1

data.name: Markov Decision Processes
data.description: The fundamental mathematical framework for RL and RL-like problems. A deep understanding of this concept is key to understanding RL.

data.name: Model-based & Model-free RL
data.description: A key differentiator that separates RL methods into two families. Model-based directly models how the environment evolves, so can simulate how an action now might affect the future states, while model-free methods do not, so can't simulate ahead.

data.name: Bellman Equations
data.description: The foundational equations of RL. These define value functions based on policies and optimal behaviour in Markov Decision Processes.

data.name: Dynamic Programming: Policy & Value Iteration
data.description: Solve MDPs exactly with these algorithms. A fundamental of RL, key aspects of these approaches are used in almost every RL algorithm.

data.name: Monte Carlo Learning
data.description: RL methods that learn from rollouts of experience in the real environment.

data.name: Value Function Approximation
data.description: Apply the Bellman Equations to approximate the value of a state. This is a key component of Q-learning, an algorithm which can achieve the optimal policy.

data.name: Actor-Critic
data.description: A family of RL methods that explicitly train a policy and a value function. These tend to learn faster than both value-based RL methods or policy-based methods.

data.name: Q-learning
data.description: As the first RL approach to achieve superhuman play on Atari games, Q-learning has cemented its place as a key RL algorithm.

data.name: Exploration & Exploitation
data.description: A classic dichotomy for RL - should I explore (and learn more about the environment) or exploit (and do what I already know works to achieve higher rewards)? How should I balance these two?

data.name: Markov Random Fields
data.description: Markov Random Fields (MRFs) have applications in computer vision, graphics and computational biology. They're the undirected counterpart to the directed Bayesian Networks.

data.name: Bayesian Networks
data.description: With uses ranging from prediction, anomaly detection to reasoning and decision making under uncertainty, Bayesian Networks are a highly flexible form of probabilistic graphical model. Bayesian networks are directed graphical models, showing how random variables depend on one another.

data.name: Variable Elimination
data.description: The most basic exact inference algorithm for probabilistic graphical models.

data.name: Belief Propagation
data.description: An algorithm for inference in graphical models using message-passing

data.name: Policy Gradient Methods
data.description: A family of model-free RL methods based on the policy gradient theorem. It's most notable members include PPO, TRPO and REINFORCE.

data.name: TD & TD(lambda) learning
data.description: Temporal Difference (or TD) learning refers to RL methods that learn online while interacting with an environment

data.name: Stochastic Gradient Descent
data.description: The key algorithm used to train the majority of deep learning methods. If it's deep and it learns, chances are it's using SGD!
